revision.text:
Dr '''Alexandre Krieps''' (born 25 June 1946 in [[Guildford]], [[United Kingdom]]) is a [[Luxembourg]]ish politician for the [[Democratic Party (Luxembourg)|Democratic Party]] (DP).<ref name="Chamber">{{cite web|url=http://www.chd.lu/fr/organisation/membres/membres.jsp?ID=109 |title=Alexandre Krieps |accessdate=2008-01-03 |publisher=[[Chamber of Deputies of Luxembourg|Chamber of Deputies]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080504213002/http://www.chd.lu/fr/organisation/membres/membres.jsp?ID=109 |archivedate=2008-05-04 |language=fr |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> He is a member of the [[Chamber of Deputies of Luxembourg|Chamber of Deputies]], representing the [[Circonscription Centre (Luxembourg)|Centre]] constituency, where the DP is strongest. He was first elected in [[Luxembourgian legislative election, 1999|1999]], but lost his seat in the [[Luxembourgian legislative election, 2004|2004 election]], in which the DP fared poorly. He returned to the Chamber on 10 October 2006,<ref name="Chamber" /> replacing [[Niki Bettendorf]] upon Bettendorf's resignation.
Krieps was born in [[Guildford]], [[Surrey]], when his father, fellow politician and [[Resistance during World War II|resistance]] leader [[Émile Krieps]], was posted in the [[United Kingdom]] in the aftermath the [[World War II|Second World War]].
He is currently President of the [[Luxembourg Rugby Federation]], a position that he had previously held from 1985 to 1992. He is a [[general practitioner]] by trade.<ref name="Chamber" />
==Footnotes== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.chd.lu/fr/organisation/membres/membres.jsp?ID=109 Chamber of Deputies official biography]

{{Luxembourg-politician-stub}}

revision.text:
[[File:Attributable fraction for the population.svg|alt=Illustration of the population, with a part exposed to a risk factor. (AFp = 1/9).|thumb|A quarter of the population is exposed to a risk factor (radiation hazard sign) and has a higher risk of an adverse outcome (black). In the whole population, one ninth of the adverse outcomes can be attributed to the exposure (AF<sub>p</sub> = 1/9).]] In [[epidemiology]], '''attributable fraction for the population (AFp)''' is the proportion of incidents in the population that are attributable to the risk factor. Term '''attributable risk percent for the population''' is used if the fraction is expressed as a percentage.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/acref/9780199976720.001.0001/acref-9780199976720|title=Dictionary of Epidemiology - Oxford Reference|language=en|doi=10.1093/acref/9780199976720.001.0001|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref> It is calculated as <math>AF_p = (I_p - I_u)/I_p</math>, where <math>I_p</math> is the incidence in the population, and <math>I_u</math> is the incidence in the unexposed group.<ref name=":0" />
Equivalently it can be calculated as <math>AF_p = \frac{P_e(RR - 1)}{1 + P_e(RR-1)}</math>, where <math>P_e</math>is the exposed proportion of the population and <math>RR</math> is the [[relative risk]] not adjusted for [[Confounding|confounders]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{cite book | url = https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/646751070 | title = Statistical methods in medical research | vauthors = Armitage P, Berry G, Matthews JN | date = 2002 | publisher = Blackwell Scientific Publications | year = 2002 | isbn = 978-0-470-77366-6 | edition = 4th | location = Oxford | pages = 682 | oclc = 646751070 }}</ref>
It is used when an exposure increases the risk, as opposed to reducing it, in which case its symmetrical notion is [[preventable fraction for the population]].
== Synonyms == Multiple synonyms of the attributable fraction for the population are in use: attributable proportion for the population<ref name=":0" />, population attributable proportion<ref name=":0" />, Levin's attributable risk,<ref name=":0" /> population attributable risk,<ref name=":1" /> population attributable fraction.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Rockhill B, Newman B, Weinberg C | title = Use and misuse of population attributable fractions | journal = American Journal of Public Health | volume = 88 | issue = 1 | pages = 15–9 | date = January 1998 | pmid = 9584027 | pmc = 1508384 }}</ref><ref name=":2">{{cite web | url = http://www.who.int/healthinfo/global_burden_disease/metrics_paf/en/ | title = Metrics: Population Attributable Fraction (PAF)| publisher = World Health Organization | access-date=2018-05-09 }}</ref>
Similarly, population attributable risk percent (PAR) is used as a synonym for the attributable risk percent for the population.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name="pmid51604333">{{cite journal | vauthors = Cole P, MacMahon B | title = Attributable risk percent in case-control studies | journal = British Journal of Preventive & Social Medicine | volume = 25 | issue = 4 | pages = 242–4 | date = November 1971 | pmid = 5160433 | pmc = 478665 | doi = }}</ref>
== Interpretation == Attributable fraction for the population combines both the relative risk of an incident with respect to the factor, as well as the prevalence of the factor in the population. Values of AF<sub>p</sub> close to 1 indicate that both the relative risk is high, and that the risk factor is prevalent. In such case, removal of the risk factor will greatly reduce the number of the incidents in the population. The values of AF<sub>p</sub> close to 0, on the other hand, indicate that either the relative risk is low, or that the factor is not prevalent (or both). Removal of such factor from the population will have little effect. Because of this interpretation, the AFp is well suited for the public policy making.<ref name=":3">{{cite journal|vauthors=Northridge ME|date=September 1995|title=Public health methods--attributable risk as a link between causality and public health action|journal=American Journal of Public Health|volume=85|issue=9|pages=1202–4|pmc=1615585|pmid=7661224}}</ref>
For example, in 1953 Levin's paper it was estimated that lung cancer has relative risk of 3.6 - 13.4 in smokers compared to non-smokers, and that the proportion of the population exposed to smoking was 0.5 - 0.96, resulting in the high value of attributable fraction for the population 0.56 - 0.92.<ref name=":3" />
== Generalizations == Attributable fraction for the population can be generalized to the case where the multilevel exposure to the risk factor. In such case
<math>AF_p = \frac{\sum_i P_i RR_r - \sum_i P_i'RR_i}{\sum_i P_i RR_i}</math>where <math>P_i</math>is the proportion of the population exposed to the level <math>i</math>, <math>P_i'</math>is the desired (ideal) proportion of the population exposed to the level <math>i</math>, and <math>RR_i</math>is the relative risk at exposure level <math>i</math>.<ref name=":2" />
== See also ==
*[[Population Impact Measures]] *[[Attributable fraction among the exposed]]
== References == {{reflist}}
{{Medical research studies}}

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox website |name = BeingGirl |logo = |logocaption = |screenshot = |collapsible = |collapsetext = |caption = Screenshot of Beinggirl.com taken on 17 March 2013 |url = {{url|beinggirl.com}}{{cite book|author=Robert L. Dilenschneider|title=The AMA Handbook of Public Relations|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=03GGtECvfI8C&pg=PA19|accessdate=24 January 2013|date=17 February 2010|publisher=AMACOM Div American Mgmt Assn|isbn=978-0-8144-1525-2|page=19}}</ref> |commercial = Yes |type = [[Inbound marketing]], [[Self care]] |registration = Optional |content license = |owner = [[Procter & Gamble]] |launch date = {{Start date and age|2000|07}}<ref name="wired 2000">{{cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/techbiz/media/news/2000/07/37788 |title=Dancing tampons |work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |date=July 26, 2000 |accessdate=March 30, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121108005947/http://www.wired.com/techbiz/media/news/2000/07/37788 |archivedate=November 8, 2012 |df=mdy }}</ref> |alexa = |revenue = |current status = Online |footnotes = }} '''BeingGirl''' is a "kid-friendly"<ref name="theglobeandmail pearce 2007">{{cite news | url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/cashing-in-on-preteen-puberty/article797684/ | title=Cashing in on preteen puberty |work=Globe and Mail |location=Canada | date=November 13, 2007 | accessdate=March 30, 2012 | author=Pearce, Tralee}}</ref> [[web site]] targeted at adolescent girls<ref name="nytimes rich 2006">{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/06/12/business/media/12book.html | title=Product Placement Deals Make Leap From Film to Books |work=New York Times | date=June 12, 2006 | accessdate=March 29, 2012 | author=Rich, Motoko}}</ref><ref name="Baelo-Allué2011">{{cite book|author=Sonia Baelo-Allué|title=Bret Easton Ellis's Controversial Fiction: Writing Between High and Low Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ik5h4WB6McoC&pg=PA104|accessdate=24 January 2013|date=23 June 2011|publisher=Continuum International Publishing Group|isbn=978-1-4411-0791-6|page=104}}</ref> created in 2000 by [[consumer goods]] company [[Procter & Gamble]] (P&G).<ref name="beinggirl">{{cite web | url=http://www.beinggirl.com/ | title=beinggirl.com | publisher=[[Procter & Gamble]] | accessdate=March 29, 2012}}</ref>
It provides information and advice. It is also a marketing tool.
== History == The site was created in 2000,<ref name="nytimes martin 2011" /> with P&G including content provided by experts.<ref name="hbr lee 2012">{{cite web | url=http://blogs.hbr.org/cs/2012/04/five_things_customers_can_do_b.html | title=The Things Customers Can Do Better Than You | publisher=[[Harvard Business Review]] | work=HBR Blog | date=April 5, 2012 | accessdate=April 23, 2012 | author=Lee, Bill}}</ref> Its development was led by the company's Tampax brand<ref name="Martin2009" /><ref name="JiwaniSteenbergen2006">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ekgox-QMlSMC&pg=PA203|title=Girlhood: Redefining the Limits|author1=Jiwani|first=Yasmin|author2=Steenbergen|first2=Candis|author3=Mitchell|first3=Claudia|publisher=Black Rose Books Ltd.|year=2006|isbn=978-1-55164-276-5|location=|pages=203|author-link=Yasmin Jiwani|accessdate=24 January 2013}}</ref> and feminine care group.<ref name="BarwiseMeehan2011">{{cite book|author1=[[Patrick Barwise]]|author2=Sean Meehan|title=Beyond the Familiar: Long-Term Growth through Customer Focus and Innovation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hZNvPBNlhBEC&pg=PA84|accessdate=23 January 2013|date=19 September 2011|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-0-470-97650-0|page=84}}</ref> [[Internet forum|Forum]]s were later added, in order to build interest. This enables girls to discuss things with each other, facilitating more subtle and effective marketing by the company.<ref name="hbr lee 2012" /> Company representatives "play an active role" in this [[user-generated content]].<ref name="ShankarCarpenter2012">{{cite book|author1=Venkatesh Shankar|author2=Gregory S. Carpenter|title=Handbook of Marketing Strategy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_qpCxOdBRScC&pg=PA207|accessdate=24 January 2013|date=12 June 2012|publisher=Edward Elgar Publishing|isbn=978-1-84980-098-3|pages=207}}</ref>
{{As of|2006}}, the website was available in 25 countries.<ref name="ShethSisodia2006" /> Its content editor in 2005 was author [[Marcia Byalick]].<ref name="CanfieldHansen2005">{{cite book|author1=Jack Canfield|author2=Mark Victor Hansen|author3=Susan L. Hendrix|title=Chicken Soup for the Soul Healthy Living: Menopause|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u_Fbs5MHD9UC&pg=PA130|accessdate=23 January 2013|year=2005|publisher=HCI Books|isbn=978-0-7573-0273-2|page=130}}</ref>
== Features ==
The site provides information and expert advice on topical [[self care]] issues such as [[menstruation]], [[eating disorder]]s, [[acne]] and [[dating]],<ref name="HaffnerTartaglione2009">{{cite book|author1=Debra W. Haffner|author2=Alyssa Haffner Tartaglione|title=Beyond the Big Talk: A Parent's Guide to Raising Sexually Healthy Teens — From Middle School to High School and Beyond|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4SQOM0S0acsC&pg=PT205|accessdate=24 January 2013|date=21 July 2009|publisher=HarperCollins|isbn=978-1-55704-866-0|page=205}}</ref> by taking a "big-sister approach".<ref name="Young2007">{{cite book|author=Antony Young|title=Profitable Marketing Communications: A Guide to Marketing Return on Investment|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b1--QVlSoagC&pg=PA89|accessdate=23 January 2013|date=3 March 2007|publisher=Kogan Page Publishers|isbn=978-0-7494-5142-4|page=89}}</ref> Features such as [[self-discovery]] quizzes are also included.<ref name="Arvidsson2006">{{cite book|author=Adam Arvidsson|title=Brands: Meaning and Value in Media Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f6vpNtG7PD4C&pg=PA101|accessdate=24 January 2013|year=2006|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0-415-34716-7|pages=102}}</ref> It also advertises some of [[list of Procter & Gamble brands|the company's products]]<ref name="nytimes martin 2011">{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/13/business/13advice.html | title=As the Web Turns |work=New York Times | date=January 12, 2011 | accessdate=March 29, 2012 | author=Martin, Andrew}}</ref><ref name="Young2007" /> and has offered free samples from [[Always (brand)|Always]] and [[Tampax]].<ref name="imediaconnection nutter 2009">{{cite news | url=http://www.imediaconnection.com/article_full.aspx?id=24241 | title=5 rules for marketing in niche social networks | work=iMediaConnection | date=August 31, 2009 | accessdate=March 30, 2012 | author=Nutter, Blaise | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121006210449/http://www.imediaconnection.com/article_full.aspx?id=24241 | archivedate=October 6, 2012 | df=mdy-all }}</ref> The information is provided using "cool teenage-girl vocabulary".<ref name="ShethSisodia2006">{{cite book|author1=Jagdish N. Sheth|author2=Rajendra S. Sisodia|title=Does Marketing Need Reform?: Fresh Perspectives on the Future|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lE7hKDryeuMC&pg=PA111|accessdate=23 January 2013|year=2006|publisher=M.E. Sharpe|isbn=978-0-7656-1699-9|page=111}}</ref>
In addition to offering advice, the site gathers information from questions asked anonymously by visitors. This is used for [[inbound marketing|inbound]] [[internet marketing]] of its products, being judged by co-author of social technologies book ''[[Groundswell (book)|Groundswell]]'', Josh Bernoff, as being four times as cost-effective as advertising.<ref name="pressdemocrat alverson 2008">{{cite news | url=http://www.pressdemocrat.com/article/20080424/NEWS/804240362 | title=Finding direction as Web 2.0 changes | work=PressDemocrat.com | date=April 24, 2008 | accessdate=March 29, 2012 | author=Halverson, Nathan}}</ref><ref name="Martin2009">{{cite book|author=Dick Martin|title=Secrets of the Marketing Masters: What the Best Marketers Do--And Why It Works|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IK4ofk6dhIIC&pg=PA151|accessdate=23 January 2013|date=15 May 2009|publisher=AMACOM Div American Mgmt Assn|isbn=978-0-8144-0943-5|page=151}}</ref> The site facilitates [[data collection]] and [[market testing]].<ref name="O'GuinnAllen2011">{{cite book|author1=Thomas C. O'Guinn|author2=Chris T. Allen|author3=Richard J. Semenik|title=Advertising and Integrated Brand Promotion|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IM_Bw9i4MdgC&pg=PA111|accessdate=23 January 2013|date=16 February 2011|publisher=Cengage Learning|isbn=978-0-538-47332-3|page=110}}</ref><ref name="O'GuinnAllen2010">{{cite book|author1=O'Guinn|author2=Allen|author3=Richard J. Semenik|title=Promo|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=osciutyVQBAC&pg=PT76|accessdate=24 January 2013|date=26 June 2010|publisher=Cengage Learning|isbn=978-0-538-47327-9|pages=62}}</ref> [[Sociologist]] [[Adam Arvidsson]], writing in 2006, analysed the site's premise as being that "engagement in community-like interaction will generate emotional and experiential ties" in consumers. They will consequently relate positively to the brand, which will raise the brand's [[equity (finance)|equity]].<ref name="Arvidsson2006" />
== Marketing agreements == The authors and publishers of 2006 novel ''[[Cathy's Book]]'' agreed with P&G to include references to the [[CoverGirl]] makeup line in exchange for promoting the book on BeingGirl.<ref name="nytimes rich 2006" /><ref name="nytimes petrecca 2006">{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/19/books/19cathy.html | title=Authors strike deals to squeeze in a few brand names |work=USA Today | date=September 10, 2006 | accessdate=March 30, 2012 | author=Petrecca, Laura}}</ref><ref name="denverpost deam 2006">{{cite news | url=http://www.denverpost.com/lifestyles/ci_4327316 | title=Selling a book by its CoverGirl |work=The Denver Post | date=September 13, 2006 | accessdate=March 30, 2012 | author=Deam, Jenny}}</ref> No monetary payment was involved.<ref name="BettigHall2012">{{cite book|author1=Ronald V. Bettig|author2=Jeanne Lynn Hall|title=Big Media, Big Money: Cultural Texts and Political Economics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WIkDpKiQpfcC&pg=PA208|accessdate=23 January 2013|date=4 May 2012|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=978-1-4422-0427-0|page=208}}</ref> The references were deleted in the novel's paperback edition.<ref name="nytimes petrecca 2006" /> Also in 2006, [[Sony BMG]] partnered with P&G to feature its artists on the site.<ref name="nytimes deutsch 2006">{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/05/09/business/media/09adco.html | title=Trying to Make Teenage Hygiene Hip |work=New York Times | date=May 9, 2006 | accessdate=March 30, 2012 | author=Deutsch, Claudia H.}}</ref> David G. Knox, a teenage market specialist in P&G's beauty division said that they approached Sony in order for teens to associate their brands with stars such as singer-songwriter [[Teddy Geiger]].<ref name="nytimes deutsch 2006" />
== Reception == {{Quote box |quote = It's a safe place where they can go for information about changes they are experiencing but are too embarrassed to discuss. |source = Velvet Gogol Bennett, P&G's North America feminine care external relations manager ({{nowrap|January 2011}})<ref name="dmnews palmer 2011">{{cite news | url=http://www.dmnews.com/marketers-strike-a-balance-between-skeptical-teens-and-their-cautious-parents/article/193154/ | title=Marketers strike a balance between skeptical teens and their cautious parents | work=Direct Marketing News | date=January 1, 2011 | accessdate=March 30, 2012 | author=Palmer, Alex}}</ref> |width = 30% |align = right |qalign = right |quoted = 1 }} The Taiwan site attracted 6000 registered members in the three months since launch in 2002.<ref name="campaignlive hille 2002">{{cite news | url=http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/News/EmailThisArticle/139980/CONNECTIONS-Whisper-site-banks-club-appeal | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120603162226/http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/News/EmailThisArticle/139980/CONNECTIONS-Whisper-site-banks-club-appeal | dead-url=yes | archive-date=June 3, 2012 | title=CONNECTIONS: Whisper site banks on club appeal | work=Campaign | date=February 22, 2002 | accessdate=March 30, 2012 | author=Hille, Alfred | publisher=[[Haymarket Media Group]] }}</ref> {{As of|2010}}, it was receiving in excess of {{nowrap|2 million}} hits worldwide per month.<ref name="Hill2010">{{cite book|author=Dan Hill|title=About Face: The Secrets of Emotionally Effective Advertising|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UCdvvsZC9isC&pg=PA149|accessdate=23 January 2013|date=3 September 2010|publisher=Kogan Page Publishers|isbn=978-0-7494-5923-9|page=149}}</ref> Its "successful engagement of teen girls" has been largely attributed to the company "stay[ing] in the background".<ref name="Bhalla2011">{{cite book|author=Gaurav Bhalla|title=Collaboration and Co-Creation: New Platforms for Marketing and Innovation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Rw02EWiLZcQC&pg=PA72|accessdate=23 January 2013|date=1 January 2011|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-1-4419-7082-4|page=69}}</ref> Its Indian site was launched in 2006, which Nikhil Pahwa on the ''contentsutra'' blog observed to "lack the freedom of a social networking space", such as [[Hindustan Unilever]]'s Sunsilk Gang of Girls.<ref name="contentsutra pahwa 2006">{{cite web | url=http://paidcontent.org/2006/11/20/pg-launches-branded-space-beinggirlcoin/ | title=P&G Launches Branded Space – BeingGirl.co.in | publisher=[[GigaOM]] | work=contentsutra | date=November 20, 2006 | accessdate=January 24, 2013 | author=Pahwa, Nikhil}}</ref> Writing in 2006, Sheth and Sisodia noted that the open discussion (in [[real life]]) by teenage girls of feminine hygiene products may be difficult in some countries.<ref name="ShethSisodia2006" />
In 2011, the charity [[Mothers' Union]] criticised the site for being "clearly a marketing tool" and Rebecca Morgan of the [[London Feminist Network]] linked references to [[hair removal]] and erotic underwear with the sexualisation of childhood.<ref name="guardian atherton 2011">{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/money/2011/aug/23/beinggirl-accused-exploiting-teenage-girls | title=BeingGirl website accused of 'exploiting' teenage girls |work=The Guardian | date=August 23, 2011 | accessdate=March 30, 2012 | author=Atherton, Sophie | author2=Smithers, Rebecca}}</ref> Research fellow at the [[University of York]], Dr Merran Toerien, criticised the site's attitude in advertising to such a young age group.<ref name="guardian atherton 2011" />
Some reviewers evaluated the health content as being "useful and well presented", although concern was expressed about the number of product mentions.<ref name="Martin2009" /> Some of the [[weight-loss]] tips were seen by some as "enabling [[eating-disorder]] behavior".<ref name="Martin2009" />
A P&G spokeswoman said that the site's "broader personal wellbeing educational scheme was strongly supported by schools".<ref name="guardian atherton 2011" /> {{Clear}}
== References == {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
{{Procter & Gamble}}
[[Category:Marketing websites]] [[Category:Health websites]] [[Category:Procter & Gamble]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2000]]

revision.text:
Berman Medical Library is located in the Ein Kerem Campus of the [[Hebrew University]]. The library provides services to the research staff and the students of the Faculties of medicine, pharmacy, nursing, dentistry, public health and occupational therapy, and the clinical-academic staff in the [[Hadassah Medical Center]].
== History == Berman Medical Library was founded in 1919 with great help of Dr. Julius Jarcho, a consulting gynecologist of [[Mount Sinai Beth Israel|Beth Israel]] and [[Sydenham Hospital]]s. In 1930 the library was named in his honour, ''The Dr. Julius Jarcho Medical Library.''<ref name="NamedJarcho">{{cite news|title=204 Students Now Attending Hebrew University; Medical Library Named for Jarcho|url=http://archive.jta.org/1930/12/28/archive/204-students-now-attending-hebrew-university-medical-library-named-for-jarcho|accessdate=18 January 2017|publisher=[[Jewish Telegraphic Agency]]|date=28 December 1930}}</ref><ref name="HonorJarcho">{{cite news|title=Pays Honor to Dr. Jarcho; University In Jerusalem Gives His Name to Library He Aided|publisher=[[New York Times]]|date=28 December 1930}}</ref> In the early days the library served as the central medical library in Israel, with branches across the country. In 1966 the Library merged with the Hadassah Medical Center. In 1975 the library moved to its current building, donated by [https://www.lehigh.edu/library/speccoll/berman.html Muriel and Philip Berman] of [[Allentown, Pennsylvania]]. Since about 2000 the library has also included a medical history museum. Since 2003 the library has been administratively incorporated in the [http://lib-authority.huji.ac.il/ University Library Authority].
Dr. Siegfried Plaschkes was the creator of the medical history museum. The Museum was transferred to the Berman Medical Library at the beginning of the millennium. It contains collections of Hebrew amulets, medals, ex-libris, medical stamps, a number of ancient instruments, and more.<ref name="SiegelItzkovich">{{cite news|last1=Siegel-Itzkovich|first1=Judy|title=Combining old and new to teach medical students|url=http://www.jpost.com/Business-and-Innovation/Health-and-Science/Combining-old-and-new-to-teach-medical-students-407335|accessdate=18 January 2017|publisher=[[Jerusalem Post]]|date=28 June 2015}}</ref><ref name="HonorBermans">{{cite news|title=HEBREW UNIVERSITY TO HONOR BERMANS AS 'FRIENDS OF ISRAEL'|url=http://articles.mcall.com/1984-10-24/news/2447821_1_mrs-berman-scopus-award-hebrew-university|accessdate=18 January 2017|publisher=[[The Morning Call]]|date=24 October 1984}}</ref> The collection of [http://www.jpost.com/Business-and-Innovation/Health-and-Science/Combining-old-and-new-to-teach-medical-students-407335 historical works and literature] is the most significant in the country. The collection donated by Dr. Süssman Muntner, dealing primarily with Maimonides.
The Division of the History of Medicine is located within Berman Medical Library. Prof. [https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/medical-history/article/div-classtitlejoshua-o-leibowitz-18951993div/AFFE4C993EFF2C4E2E9D153EAC0A88AE Joshua O. Leibowitz] (1895-1993) was the first head of the division. Prof. Joshua O. Leibowitz was for several years the President of the International Academy of the History of Medicine. His follower, Prof. [[:fr:Samuel_S._Kottek|Samuel S. Kottek]] (emeritus) was the second head, from 1975 till 2000. The Division is now headed by Dr. [http://paincenter.huji.ac.il/dror.htm Otniel Dror], MD, PhD. The unit provides teaching, ongoing research, and tutoring of MD and PhD theses.
==References== {{reflist}}

page.title: Birth as an American Rite of Passage

revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=June 2017}}{{Italic title}}
'''''Birth as an American Rite of Passage''''' is a book written by [[Robbie Davis-Floyd]] and published in 1992. It combines anthropology and first-hand accounts from mothers and doctors into a critical analysis of childbirth in America from a [[Feminism|feminist]] perspective.
It introduces the theme of technocratic medicine as a form of indoctrination into America's [[patriarchal]] culture. Davis-Floyd argues that American birthing practices value science over nature, a doctor's knowledge over that of the mother and that many common actions performed by doctors (or the mother) are [[technocratic]] rituals – behaviors with limited practical purpose. She cites practices such as obstructing the mother's line of sight to the baby exiting her body by placing a sheet over her lower body. Davis-Floyd believes that society, intimidated by women's ability to give birth, has designed unnecessary rituals in order to make the symbolism of childbirth available to everyone, not just those who can bear children. "In this way," she writes, "society symbolically demonstrates ownership of its product."<ref>{{Cite book|title=Birth as an American Rite of Passage|last=Davis-Floyd|first=Robbie|publisher=University of California Press|year=1992|isbn=9780520074392|location=|pages=}}</ref>
== Key concepts == ===Technology in birth=== Major life transitions are often [[Ritualization|ritualized]] in a way that is local to a particular society or culture.<ref>Davis-Floyd, Robbie. "The Rituals of American Hospital Birth," ‘’Conformity and Conflict: Readings in Cultural Anthropology’’ (1994) pp 1-20. [http://www.davis-floyd.com/the-rituals-of-american-hospital-birth/]</ref> Pregnancy and childbirth are processes that reflect the traditions, beliefs, and values of the culture in which they take place.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Julia W. Buckey|first=George A. Jacinto|year=2013|title=Birth: A Rite of Passage|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/George_Jacinto/publication/270571428_Birth_A_Rite_of_Passage/links/56a256a508ae232fb2019b18.pdf|journal=International Journal of Childbirth Education|volume=|pages=}}</ref> Davis-Floyd argues that the emphasis on technological advances that aid pregnancy, create a negative effect surrounding its [[ideology]]. The book argues that American society values the knowledge of medical professionals over that of mothers and [[Midwife|midwives]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Childbirth_and_Authoritative_Knowledge.html?id=qo-1ngEACAAJ|title=Childbirth and Authoritative Knowledge: Cross-cultural Perspectives|last=Davis-Floyd|first=Robbie|last2=Sargent|first2=Carolyn Fishel|date=1997-01-01|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=9780520207851|language=en}}</ref> Davis-Floyd's model criticizes current [[Obstetrics and gynaecology|tocology]] and childbirth as overly scientific, technology-motivated methods that can serve to disempower women. Certain medical procedures such as a [[Caesarean section|cesarean section]], [[episiotomy]], and the positioning of the woman at the time of birth, are viewed as optimal in American birthing culture.<ref>{{Cite web|jstor=10.1525/j.ctt1ppszz|title=Birth Models That Work|last=Davis-Floyd|first=Robbie|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Davis-Floyd argues that these procedures are mainly a result of cultural beliefs, and not for their actual benefits. The same is true of the perception that pregnancy and childbirth require medical oversight and interference. Davis-Floyd claims that the majority of women's favorable views of technological intervention during childbirth are due to doctors' influence. Obstetric procedures act as rituals for pregnant women and medical personnel, with the intention of improving the attitudes of those involved in birthing. For example, when fluids are administered through [[intravenous therapy]], a feeling of security is invoked; a reassuring order is imposed on the event, reinforcing reliance upon others' knowledge.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.davis-floyd.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Davis-Floyd-1994-The-Technocratic-Body-American-Childbirth-as-Cultural-Expression.pdf|title=The Technocratic Body: American Childbirth as Cultural Expression|last=Davis-Floyd|first=Robbie|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stthomasu.ca/~parkhill/rite101/ireps/floyd.htm|title=Medicalization of Birth|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Intuition as Authoritative Knowledge in Midwifery and Home birth|last=Davis-Floyd|first=Robbie|date=|website=|jstor=649330|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
===Rite of passage=== The concept of a [[rite of passage]] was coined by [[Ethnography|ethnographer]] [[Arnold van Gennep]].{{cn|date=May 2018}} Davis-Floyd states that birth as a rite of passage incorporates three essential stages. Through birth, the treatment of the woman's body, and the doctor's implementation of procedures, the rite is enacted within American culture.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sscnet.ucla.edu/anthro/faculty/browner/publications/brownerpress1996.pdf|title=The Production of Authoritative Knowledge in American Prenatal Care|last=Press|first=Nancy|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
===Stages=== The three stages are separation, [[liminality|pregnancy]] and reincorporation. These three stages characterize the rite of passage and are culturally relative to the society within which they function. In some cases four stages apply, and in rare cases, up to ten. However, such cases have never been recorded.{{Clarify|reason=how can they be said to exist if they have not been recorded?|date=May 2018}}
'''Separation''': A phase during which the pregnant woman begins to form a new self-identity as a result of her pregnancy. She separates from her original state of being. In this stage, the woman is now an "other", unlike her old self.
'''Pregnancy''': A phase where the pregnant woman is "in between". She is neither a normal member of society nor a mother. This stage continues until after the birth.
'''Integration''': The woman accepts her new social identity. This phase ends when the woman feels that she is similar to her previous self.
== Reception == Reviews of this book praised Davis-Floyd for connecting American childbirth with rituals using an anthropological basis. The book also received criticism for basing its conclusions on interviews with only 100 women who were all well-educated, middle-class and [[Caucasian race|Caucasian]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Birth as an American Rite of Passage Review|last=Phillips|first=Virginia|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1992 books]] [[Category:Human pregnancy]] [[Category:Childbirth in the United States]]

'''Born in Bradford'''<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.borninbradford.nhs.uk/| title=Born in Bradford Official Website|date=2013-10-28}}</ref> is a large birth cohort study based at [[Bradford Royal Infirmary]], a hospital in the city of [[Bradford]], [[West Yorkshire]] in the [[United Kingdom]]. 12,500 pregnant women were recruited to the study between March 2007 and December 2010. The lives of their 13,500 children are being tracked through research studies and the use of routinely collected medical and educational data.
==Background== Bradford has some of the highest rates of childhood illness in the UK. Born in Bradford is helping to unravel the reasons for this ill health and bring new scientific discovery to the world.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.borninbradford.nhs.uk/news/| title=Born in Bradford News|date=2013-10-28}}</ref> It is also providing a catalyst for communities to work with the NHS and local authority to improve child health and wellbeing in the city. Examples of the success of Born in Bradford in changing practice include: the establishment of a Yorkshire wide congenital anomalies register, the first trust in the UK to provide gestational diabetes screening for all pregnant women in the district, improvement in vitamin D supplementation in high risk mothers, rapid implementation of [[NICE]] guidelines in midwifery practice, improved detection of childhood obesity by health visitors, and development of a simple mobile phone app to help parents and health professionals monitor children's weight.
Born in Bradford will continue to follow children until they are adults, and help doctors to understand more about the big health challenges of the 21st century such as heart disease, mental health and cancer. This is a study that has the potential to promote real change at a local level and also to make major contributions to global knowledge.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.borninbradford.nhs.uk/research-scientific/bib-scientific-publications/| title=Born in Bradford Scientific Publications|date=2013-10-28}}</ref>
==Further reading==
* {{cite journal|last=Raynor|first= P.|author2=and Born in Bradford Collaborative Group |journal=BMC Public Health|doi=10.1186/1471-2458-8-327|title=Born in Bradford, a cohort study of babies born in Bradford, and their parents: protocol for the recruitment phase|date=2008|volume=8|issue=1|pages=327|pmid=18811926|pmc=2562385}} * {{cite journal|last=Wright|first= J.|author2=[[Neil Small|Small, N.]] |others= Raynor, P., Tuffnell, D., Bhopal, R., Cameron, N., Fairley L., Lawlor D.,Parslow R., Petherick ES., Pickett K., West J., Waibinger D. and the Born in Bradford Scientific Collaborators' Group |journal=International Journal of Epidemiology|doi=10.1093/ije/dys112|title=Cohort Profile: The Born in Bradford multi-ethnic family cohort study|date=2012|volume=42|issue=4|pages=978–991|pmid=23064411}}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [https://www.facebook.com/BornInBradford/ Born in Bradford Facebook page]
[[Category:Bradford]] [[Category:Health in Yorkshire]] [[Category:Cohort studies]]

<!-- Article title: CBC Bank SHRNo:143 DatabaseNo:5045696 --> {{Use Australian English|date=June 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox historic site | name = CBC Bank | image = | caption = | locmapin = New South Wales | map_caption = | coordinates = {{coord|-34.6724|150.8566|region:AU-NSW_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | map_relief = yes | location = 16-20 Manning Street, [[Kiama, New South Wales|Kiama]], [[Municipality of Kiama]], [[New South Wales]], Australia | area = | elevation = | height = | beginning_label = Design period | beginning_date = | formed = | founded = | built = 1880 | built_for = | demolished = | architect = Mansfield Bros | architecture = | owner = | designation1 = New South Wales State Heritage Register | designation1_offname = CBC Bank (former); Kiama Veterinary service; Commercial Banking Company of Sydney Ltd | designation1_type = state heritage (built) | designation1_date = 2 April 1999 | delisted1_date = | designation1_partof = | designation1_number = 143 | designation1_free1name = Type | designation1_free1value = Bank | designation1_free2name = Category | designation1_free2value = Commercial | designation1_free3name = Builders | designation1_free3value = White and Coghill }}
'''CBC Bank''' is a heritage-listed former bank building at 16-20 Manning Street, [[Kiama, New South Wales|Kiama]], [[Municipality of Kiama]], [[New South Wales]], Australia. It was designed by Mansfield Bros and built by White and Coghill in 1880. It was added to the [[New South Wales State Heritage Register]] on 2 April 1999.<ref name=nswshr-143>{{cite NSW SHR|5045696|CBC Bank (former)|hr=00143|fn=S90/05746 & HC 32558|accessdate=1 June 2018}}</ref><ref name=local>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article113841533 |title=LOCAL INTELLIGENCE. |newspaper=[[The Kiama Independent, And Shoalhaven Advertiser]] |volume=XVIII, |issue=1,110 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=20 August 1880 |accessdate=20 July 2018 |page=2 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
== History ==
The building was built in 1880 for the [[Commercial Banking Company of Sydney]], with Mansfield Bros. as the architect and [[Sydney]] contractors White and Coghill as builders. It was described at its establishment by ''[[The Kiama Independent and Illawarra and Shoalhaven Advertiser]]'' as "likely to be one of the principal ornaments of Kiama".<ref name=nswshr-143/><ref name=local />
The CBC Bank shifted to new premises in Terralong Street {{circa}} 1969.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cbcbank.com.au/images/Branches/NSW/NSW%20Country/NSW%20Country%20G-L/nsw_country%20JK.htm | title=J-K NSW Country | publisher=CBC Officers Club | accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article126905890 |title=Advertising |newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]] |volume=56, |issue=17,075 |location=Australian Capital Territory, Australia |date=28 June 1982 |accessdate=20 July 2018 |page=10 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
In 1979 Mr & Mrs Roslyn McKinnon, owners of the CBC Bank, nominated it for a Permanent Conservation Order. At that time the front of the building was occupied by a solicitors practice, the rear was occupied by a veterinary surgeon and the upstairs was let as a flat. The owners of the property were seeking protection under the Heritage Act for the building with a view to attracting rating and taxation benefits.<ref name=nswshr-143/>
At its meeting of 14 January 1981 the Heritage Council recommended that a Permanent Conservation Order be placed over the former CBC Bank, Kiama.<ref name=nswshr-143/>
A Permanent Conservation Order was placed over the property on 17 July 1981.<ref name=nswshr-143/>
It was transferred to the State Heritage Register on 2 April 1999.<ref name=nswshr-143/>
It now houses IT firm DropPoint.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.droppoint.com.au/droppoint-is-moving-2/ | title=DropPoint is Moving | publisher=DropPoint | accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref>
== Description == The building falls within the Mansfield Genre of substantial and impressive two-storey Italianate-style banks consisting of ground floor banking chambers with first floor manager's residence. Materials are rendered brick and slate, and the building retains much of its original detail and joinery, little compromised by the various uses to which the former bank has been put.<ref name=nswshr-143-1016>Branch Managers Report to Heritage Council 14 January 1981</ref><ref name=nswshr-143/>
The building retains much of its original detail and joinery.<ref name=nswshr-143-1016/><ref name=nswshr-143/>
== Heritage listing == The former CBC Bank was constructed in 1880 to designs of Mansfield Bros for Commercial Banking Company of Sydney Ltd. It comes within the Mansfield genre of substantial and impressive two-storey Italianate style banks. The building retains much of its original detail and joinery. Situated adjacent to the [[Bank of New South Wales]] building, also by Mansfield Bros and near Kiama Post Office and other early commercial and civic premises, the former CBC bank is an important component of Kiama's townscape and a reminder of the town's elegant past.<ref name=nswshr-143-1016/><ref name=nswshr-143/>
CBC Bank was listed on the [[New South Wales State Heritage Register]] on 2 April 1999 having satisfied the following criteria.<ref name=nswshr-143/>
'''The place is important in demonstrating the course, or pattern, of cultural or natural history in New South Wales.'''
The former CBC Bank was constructed {{circa|1880}} to designs of Mansfield Bros for Commercial Banking Company of Sydney Ltd.<ref name=nswshr-143-1016/><ref name=nswshr-143/>
'''The place is important in demonstrating aesthetic characteristics and/or a high degree of creative or technical achievement in New South Wales.'''
It comes within the Mansfield genre of substantial and impressive two-storey Italianate style banks. Situated adjacent to the Bank of New South Wales building, also by Mansfield Bros and near Kiama Post Office and other early commercial and civic premises, the former CBC bank is an important component of Kiama's townscape and a reminder of the town's elegant past.<ref name=nswshr-143-1016/><ref name=nswshr-143/>
== See also == {{Portal|New South Wales}} == References == {{reflist}}
=== Bibliography === * {{cite book|author=|date=1981|title=Branch Managers Report to Heritage Council 14 January 1981}} === Attribution === {{NSW-SHR-CC|name=CBC Bank (former)|dno=5045696|id=00143|year=2018|accessdate=1 June 2018}}

revision.comment: +{{[[Template:Authority control|Authority control]]}} (1 source from Wikidata), [[WP:GenFixes]] on,
revision.text:
{{Infobox anatomy | Name = Carpal tunnel | Latin = Canalis carpi | Image = | Caption = | Image2 = 815 The Carpal Tunnel.jpg | Caption2 = The carpal tunnel | Precursor = | System = | Artery = | Vein = | Nerve = | Lymph = }} In the [[human body]], the '''carpal tunnel''' or '''carpal canal''' is the passageway on the [[Anatomical terms of location#Arms|palmar]] side of the [[wrist]] that connects the [[forearm]] to the [[hand]].<ref name="Schmidt-29">{{cite book | title = Surgical anatomy of the hand | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=L7a1tkBU8eMC&pg=PA29 | first1 = Hans-Martin | last1 = Schmidt | first2 = Ulrich | last2 = Lanz | publisher = Thieme | year = 2003 | page = 29 | isbn = 1-58890-007-X }}</ref>
The tunnel is bounded by the [[Carpal bones|bones of the wrist]] and [[Flexor retinaculum of the hand|flexor retinaculum]] from connective tissue. Normally several [[tendon]]s from the [[Flexor muscle|flexor]] group of [[forearm muscles]] and the [[median nerve]] pass through it. There are described cases of variable [[median artery]] occurrence.
The canal is narrow, and when any of the nine long flexor tendons passing through it [[swelling (medical)|swell]] or degenerate, the narrowing of the canal may result in the median nerve becoming entrapped or compressed, a common medical condition known as [[carpal tunnel syndrome]].<ref name="Thieme-Atlas-248">{{cite book | title = Thieme Atlas of Anatomy: General Anatomy and Musculoskeletal System | publisher = Thieme | year = 2006 | isbn = 1-58890-419-9 | pages = 248–249 }}</ref>
== Structure == [[File:Wrist MRI T1FSE PDfrFSE STIR 14.jpg|thumb|Carpal tunnel as seen on MRI]] The [[carpal bones]] that make up the wrist form an arch which is convex on the [[Anatomical terms of location#Dorsal and ventral|dorsal]] side of the hand and concave on the palmar side. The groove on the palmar side, the ''sulcus carpi'', is covered by the [[flexor retinaculum of the hand|flexor retinaculum]], a [[Tendon sheath|sheath]] of tough [[connective tissue]], thus forming the carpal tunnel. On the side of the [[radius (bone)|radius]], the flexor retinaculum is attached to the [[scaphoid bone]], more precisely its [[scaphoid bone#Bone|tubercle]], as well as the ridge of [[Trapezium (bone)|trapezium]]. On the [[ulna]]r side it is attached to the [[pisiform]] and [[hook of hamate]].<ref name="Thieme-Atlas-354">{{cite book | title = Thieme Atlas of Anatomy: General Anatomy and Musculoskeletal System | publisher = Thieme | year = 2006 | isbn = 1-58890-419-9 | page = 354 }}</ref>
The narrowest section of the tunnel is located a centimetre beyond the mid-line of the [[Anatomical terms of location|distal]] [[Carpal bones#Bones|row of carpal bones]] where the sectional area is limited to 1.6 cm<sup>2</sup>.<ref name="Thieme-Atlas-248" />
The tendons of the flexor digitorum superficialis and profundus pass through a common ulnar sheath, while the tendon of the flexor pollicis longus passes through a separate radial sheath. The [[Vinculum (ligament)|mesotendon]] shared by these tendons is attached to the radial and palmar walls of the carpal tunnel.<ref name="Thieme-Atlas-354" />
Superficial to the carpal tunnel and the flexor retinaculum, the [[ulnar artery]] and [[ulnar nerve]] pass through the [[ulnar tunnel|ulnar tunnel/Guyon's canal]].<ref name="Thieme-Atlas-354" />
==Function== [[File:Carpal-Tunnel.svg|thumb|Transverse section across the [[wrist]] and [[carpal]]s; the [[Hand#Human anatomy|palm]] is at the top (carpal tunnel not labeled but visible at centre)]] Ten structures pass through the carpal tunnel, most of them flexor tendons<ref name="Thieme-Atlas-248" /> (not the muscles themselves): * [[Flexor digitorum profundus muscle|flexor digitorum profundus]] (four tendons) * [[flexor digitorum superficialis]] (four tendons) * [[Flexor pollicis longus muscle|flexor pollicis longus]] (one tendon) * [[Median nerve]] between tendons of flexor digitorum profundus and flexor digitorum superficialis
The [[flexor carpi radialis]] (one tendon), is often incorrectly stated to travel within the carpal tunnel. More precisely, it travels within the fibers of the flexor retinaculum which forms the roof of the carpal tunnel, rather than running inside the tunnel itself. <!--* [[flexor carpi radialis muscle|flexor carpi radialis]] (one tendon), considered part of the carpal tunnel<ref name="Thieme-Atlas-354">{{cite book | title = Thieme Atlas of Anatomy: General Anatomy and Musculoskeletal System | publisher = Thieme | year = 2006 | isbn = 1-58890-419-9 | page = 354 }}</ref><ref name="med.mun.ca"">{{cite web | url = http://www.med.mun.ca/anatomyts/msk/wrist.htm | title = The wrist joint | publisher = Memorial University of Newfoundland | accessdate = 2008-01-17 }}</ref> although it is more precise to state that it travels in the [[Flexor retinaculum of the hand|flexor retinaculum]], which covers the carpal tunnel, rather than running in the tunnel itself.-->
=== Effect of wrist movements === Movements in the wrist affect the shape and width of the carpal tunnel. The width decreases considerably during normal range of motion in the wrist and because the carpal bones move in relation to each other with every motion of the hand the bony walls of the tunnel are not rigid. Both flexion and extension increase compression in the carpal tunnel.
* Flexing the wrist causes the flexor retinaculum to move closer to the radius which considerably decreases the cross section of the proximal opening of the tunnel. Additionally, the distal end of the capitate presses into the opening. * In extreme extension, the lunate constricts the passage as it is pressed toward the interior of the tunnel.<ref name="Schmidt-29" /><!--- ref for entire sub-section --->
==Clinical significance== {{main|Carpal tunnel syndrome}} [[Carpal tunnel syndrome]] is a syndrome characterised by tingling burning and pain (needle, pin) through the course of median nerve particularly over the outer fingers and radiating up the arm, that is caused by compression of the carpal tunnel contents. It is associated with repetitive use, [[rheumatoid arthritis]], and a number of other states. It can be detected using [[Tinel's sign]] and the [[Phalen maneuver]]. It may be treated non-surgically by splinting and/or corticosteroid injection, though definitive management often requires surgical division of the flexor retinaculum, which forms the roof of the carpal tunnel. Carpal tunnel symptoms can sometimes be caused by tight muscles in the neck and shoulder region.
==Additional Images== <gallery> File:Slide3VVVVV.JPG|Carpal tunnel File:Slide9VVVVV.JPG|Carpal tunnel File:Slide1dsds.JPG|Wrist joint. Deep dissection.Anterior, palmar, view. File:Slide2dsds.JPG|Wrist joint. Deep dissection.Anterior, palmar, view. File:Slide3dsds.JPG|Wrist joint. Deep dissection.Anterior, palmar, view. File:Hand dissection 5.jpg|Carpal tunnel and thenar and hypothenar eminences File:Hand dissection 9.jpg|Carpal tunnel </gallery>
==See also== {{Anatomy-terms}} *[[Carpal Tunnel Syndrome]] *[[Carpal tunnel surgery]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Carpal tunnels}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.tk.de/rochelexikon/pics/s25466.091-1.html|title=Anatomy diagram: 25466.091-1|work=Roche Lexicon - illustrated navigator|publisher=Elsevier|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140101000000/http://www.tk.de/rochelexikon/pics/s25466.091-1.html|archivedate=2014-01-01|deadurl=yes|df=}}

revision.text:
A '''Clinical Data Repository''' (CDR) or '''Clinical Data Warehouse''' (CDW) is a [[real time database]] that consolidates data from a variety of clinical sources to present a unified view of a single [[patient]]. It is optimized to allow [[clinician]]s to retrieve data for a single patient rather than to identify a population of patients with common characteristics or to facilitate the management of a specific clinical department. Typical data types which are often found within a CDR include: clinical laboratory test results, patient [[demographics]], pharmacy information, [[radiology]] reports and images, [[pathology]] reports, hospital admission, discharge and transfer dates, [[ICD-9]] codes, discharge summaries, and progress notes.<ref name=idrsurvey>{{Cite journal | last1 = MacKenzie | first1 = S. L. | last2 = Wyatt | first2 = M. C. | last3 = Schuff | first3 = R. | last4 = Tenenbaum | first4 = J. D. | last5 = Anderson | first5 = N. | title = Practices and perspectives on building integrated data repositories: Results from a 2010 CTSA survey | doi = 10.1136/amiajnl-2011-000508 | journal = Journal of the American Medical Informatics Association | volume = 19 | issue = e1 | pages = e119–e124 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22437072| pmc =3392848 }}</ref>
<!--Potential Uses-->
A Clinical Data Repository could be used in the hospital setting to track prescribing trends as well as for the monitoring of infectious diseases. One area CDR's could potentially be used is monitoring the prescribing of antibiotics in hospitals especially as the number of antiobiotic-resistant bacteria is ever increasing. In 1995, a study at the Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center conducted by the Harvard Medical School used a CDR to monitor vancomycin use and prescribing trends since vancomycin-resistant enterococci is a growing problem. They used the CDR to track the prescribing by linking the individual patient, medication, and the microbiology lab results which were all contained within the CDR. If the microbiology lab result did not support the use of vancomycin, it was suggested to change the medication to something appropriate as under the Center for Disease Control [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] guidelines. The use of CDR's could help monitor infectious diseases in the hospital and the appropriate prescribing based on lab results.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Samore M. Lichtenberg D |author2=Saubermann L |author3=Kawachi C |author4=Carmeli Y. | year = 1997| title = A Clinical Data Repository Enhances Hospital Infection Control | url = https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2233433/pdf/procamiaafs00001-0095.pdf | format = PDF | journal = Harvard Medical School | volume = 1997 | issue = | pages = 56–60 | pmc=2233433 | pmid=9357588}}</ref>
The use of Clinical Data Repositories could provide a wealth of knowledge about patients, their medical conditions, and their outcome. The database could serve as a way to study the relationship and potential patterns between disease progression and management. The term "Medical Data Mining" has been coined for this method of research. Past epidemiological studies may not have had as complete of information as that which is contained in a CDR, which could lead to inconclusive data/results. The use of medical data mining and correlative studies using the CDR could serve as a valuable resource helping the future of healthcare in all facets of medicine.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Prather JC, Lobach DF, Goodwin LK, Hales JW, Hage ML, Hammond WE | year = 1997| title = Medical Data Mining: Knowledge Discovery in a Clinical Data Warehouse | url = https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2233405/pdf/procamiaafs00001-0140.pdf | format = PDF | journal = Duke University Medical Center | volume = 1997 | issue = | pages = 101–105 | pmc=2233405 | pmid=9357597}}</ref> The idea of data mining a CDW was used for screening variables that were associated with diabetes and poor glycemic control. It allowed for novel correlations that may have not been discovered without this method.<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0933365702000519 | doi=10.1016/S0933-3657(02)00051-9 | pmid=12234716 | volume=26 | issue=1–2 | title=Data mining a diabetic data warehouse | journal=Artificial Intelligence in Medicine | pages=37–54| date=September 2002 | last1=Breault | first1=Joseph L. | last2=Goodall | first2=Colin R. | last3=Fos | first3=Peter J. }}</ref>
One potential use of a clinical data repository would be for clinical trials. This would allow for researchers to have all the information from a study in one place as well as let other researchers benefit from the data to further innovation. They would also be advantageous since they are digital and real-time. This would be easier to log data and keep it accurate since it would be digital rather than in paper form.
The clinical data repository is not without its weaknesses, however. Since they usually don't integrate with other non-clinical sources, following patient treatment across the care continuum becomes very difficult. In turn, tracking the true cost per case for each patient isn't feasible. IT teams spend most of their time gathering and compiling data instead of interpreting information and finding opportunities for cutting costs and improving patient care.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.healthcatalyst.com/clinical-data-repository-data-warehouse|title=Clinical Data Repository vs. Data Warehouse: Which Do You Need?|work=healthcatalyst.com|date=2014-07-10}}</ref>

page.title: Dignity Health St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center

revision.comment: clean up, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: 607 bed → 607-bed, h’s → h's (2)
revision.text:
{{Redirect|St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center|St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center in Tucson, Arizona|Carondelet St. Joseph's Hospital}} {{external links|date=February 2012}} {{Infobox hospital | name = Dignity Health St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center | org/group = [[Dignity Health]] | country = US <!--needed for infobox--> | founded = 1895 | logo = | image = <!-- optional --> | caption = <!-- optional --> | map_type = | map_caption = | coordinates = {{coord|33.4820477|-112.0796807|region:US-AZ|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | state = [[Arizona]] | healthcare = Private | type = Community, Teaching | speciality = <!-- if devoted to a speciality, i.e. not if has broad spectrum of specialities --> | standards = <!-- optional if no national standards --> | emergency = [[Trauma center|Level I Trauma Center]] | affiliation = [[Creighton University]] School of Medicine at St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center | beds = 607 | closed = <!-- optional --> | website = {{URL|http://dignityhealth.org/stjosephs/}} | other_links = <!-- optional --> |location=350 West Thomas Road Phoenix, Arizona 85013}}
'''Dignity Health St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center''' is a [[hospital]] in [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]], [[Arizona]], [[United States|USA]], operated by [[Dignity Health]]. St. Joseph's is a 607-bed, not-for-profit hospital that provides a wide range of health, social and support services, with special advocacy for the poor and under served. It is home to the [[Barrow Neurological Institute]], the world's largest dedicated neurosurgical center and a renowned leader in neurosurgical training, research, and patient care.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.dignityhealth.org/arizona/locations/stjosephs|title=St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center|last=|first=|date=|website=Dignity Health|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Services == St. Joseph's is a center for tertiary care, medical education and research. It includes the [[Barrow Neurological Institute]], the Heart & Lung Institute, and a Level I Trauma Center verified by the [[American College of Surgeons]]. The hospital is also a center for maternity care, orthopedics, oncology and many other medical services.
== History == The [[Sisters of Mercy]] came to Phoenix in 1892 to open a parish school. They were successful in that endeavor, but were also affected deeply by the suffering of [[tuberculosis]] victims. Realizing the most pressing need of the community, the Sisters expanded their original mission and began fund-raising to be able to establish a [[Sanatorium|sanitarium]].
Their efforts paid off. They collected enough money to rent a six-bedroom brick cottage at Fourth and Polk Streets in January 1895. They equipped each room with two beds for tuberculosis patients and created quarters for themselves in the living room. St. Joseph's Sanitarium was born.
Two months later, the Sisters had raised sufficient funds to build a "real hospital." On March 19, 1895, a stake was driven into the ground to mark the site of what would become a hospital housing 24 private rooms that opened onto porches.
Through the years, there were additions to that building, of course, and a devastating fire in 1917, after which the building was reconstructed in just 90 days. The rebuilt facility was adequate for the community for the next 30 years, but the local population was continuing to grow significantly. In 1930, the population of Phoenix was 48,118. By 1945, it had reached nearly 100,000. St. Joseph's Hospital needed a larger facility.
In the mid-1940s, the Sisters purchased {{convert|10|acre}} of land at Third Avenue and Thomas Road which was then part of an old dairy farm. They were criticized for choosing land so far north of the city, literally out in the country. But the Sisters had foresight and a keen understanding of a good business deal. Those 10 acres cost just $25,000.
In November 1947, a fundraising campaign began to raise money to build the new hospital. The facility opened in July 1953.<ref>http://www.stjosephs-phx.org/Who_We_Are/History/index.htm</ref>
In 2010, Bishop [[Thomas Olmsted]] revoked the hospital's affiliation with the [[Roman Catholic Church]] in a controversy over medical procedures and church teachings (see below).
== Facilities == St. Joseph's Hospital also has a Lung Transplant Program, which offers transplants to those individuals diagnosed with high-risk [[lung diseases]]. The program is offered through the Center of Thoracic Transplantation and has received accreditation from the [[Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services]] (CMS). On April 13, 2007, the hospital performed the first recorded [[lung transplant]] in [[Phoenix, Arizona]].<ref>[http://www.stjosephs-phx.org/stellent/groups/public/@xinternet_con_sjh/documents/webcontent/188175.pdf "13" Proving a Lucky Number for St. Joseph's Lung Transplantation Program"], Accessed October 13, 2010.</ref> Since then, more than 170 such transplants have been conducted by the program.<ref>[http://www.stjosephs-phx.org/stellent/groups/public/@xinternet_con_sjh/documents/webcontent/201042.pdf "St. Joseph's Expects Lung Transplant Program to Nearly Double after Receiving CMS Accreditation"], October 23, 2009.</ref><ref>[http://www.stjosephs-phx.org/Medical_Services/Center_for_Thoracic_Transplantation/index.htm "Center for Thoracic Transplantation"], Accessed September 24, 2010.</ref>
=== Barrow Neurological Institute === St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center is home to the [[Barrow neurological institute]] (BNI), a nationally ranked program in neurology and neurosurgery.<ref name="U.S. News & World Report">{{cite news | title=Best Hospitals 2009 Specialty Search: Neurology and neurosurgery | publisher=[[U.S. News & World Report]] | url =http://health.usnews.com/health/best-hospitals/neurology-and-neurosurgery-hospital-rankings/ | work = | accessdate = 2009-08-21 }}</ref> The BNI has the largest neurosurgery residency program in the United States, as of 2013.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Lochhead|first=R|journal=World Neurosurg|year=2010|volume=74|pages=71–80|pmid=21299987|doi=10.1016/j.wneu.2010.07.011|issue=1|title=A history of the Barrow Neurological Institute|display-authors=etal}}</ref> The current director of the BNI is vascular neurosurgeon [[Robert F. Spetzler]], a position he has held since 1986.
== Centers for Clinical Research == Dignity Health currently supports 16 internal Institutional Review Boards providing oversight for more than 1,000 clinical trials across the system. Dignity's Human Research Protection Office provides for the regulatory and compliance oversight of all research conducted at Dignity.
== Controversies == {{Main|Excommunication of Margaret McBride}} The hospital in late 2009 had as a patient a mother of four who was 11 weeks pregnant and suffering from a severe case of [[pulmonary hypertension]]. Doctors estimated that her chance of dying if she continued the pregnancy was "close to 100 percent".<ref name=McBride>{{cite news|date=2010-05-19|work=National Public Radio|title=Nun Excommunicated for Allowing Abortion|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=126985072|last=Hagerty|first=Barbara}}</ref> An ethics board approved an abortion to save the life of the mother, even though the hospital was Catholic and within the Diocese of Phoenix. A religious sister, Sister Margaret Mary McBride, who was a vice president at the hospital and who concurred in the decision, was [[excommunicated]] by [[Thomas Olmsted]], the Bishop of Phoenix.<ref>Goodstein, Laurie. "Arizona: Hospital Loses Catholic Affiliation." ''The New York Times,'' December 22, 2010, pg. A25</ref> The case stirred intense debate from within and outside the area. McBride was later returned to good standing with the church, her religious community, and the hospital.<ref>NEWS BRIEFS Dec-9-2011. [http://www.catholicnews.com/data/briefs/cns/20111209.htm#head13 Mercy nun at hospital that allowed abortion 'no longer excommunicated'] Catholic News Service. Retrieved 2012-03-23. "Sister Margaret 'met the requirements for reinstatement with the church and she is no longer excommunicated. She continues to be a member in good standing with the Sisters of Mercy and is a valued member of the St. Joseph's executive team.'"</ref>
Bishop Olmsted asked Catholic Healthcare West to provide a moral analysis of the case. He later issued a decree on 21 December 2010 revoking the hospital's affiliation with the Catholic Church, after months of discussion had failed to induce the hospital management to refuse to perform similar abortions in the future. Olmsted wrote that he could not verify that the hospital provides health care consistent with "authentic Catholic moral teaching."
== References == {{Reflist|33em}}
== External links == * {{Official website|https://www.dignityhealth.org/|name=Dignity Health Official Website}}
[[Category:Hospital buildings completed in 1953]] [[Category:Hospitals in Arizona]] [[Category:Dignity Health]] [[Category:Christian hospitals]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Phoenix, Arizona]]

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{notability|Events|date=October 2015}} {{more citations needed|date=February 2015}} {{Underlinked|date=October 2015}} }} Founded in 1967, the '''European Congress of Radiology''' was first held every four years in different locations. However, the idea of developing a new type of congress became more intensively discussed as the quadrennial basis and the ever-changing location did not allow for the creation of a consistent group of experienced [[radiologist]]s responsible for the preparation of the congress. Furthermore, the radiological community in [[Europe]] wanted to create a common platform for European radiologists.
In 1985, a committee chaired by Prof. Dr. Josef Lissner from Munich (Germany) was established to re-organise the Congress. They decided that it should take place every two years and that the location should not change. Vienna was soon selected, due to its geographical location in the heart of Europe. The society ‘Verein Europäischer Röntgenkongress’ (ECR) was founded, and a congress-organising institution was established at the Medical Academy of Vienna.
The first ‘new’ European Congress of Radiology was opened on Saturday, September 15, 1991 under the presidency of Prof. Dr. Lissner. It attracted more than 9,000 participants from around the world.
The two-year cycle of the congress was continued until 1999, when it was decided that the rapid development of the medical specialty of radiology required an annual meeting of Europe’s radiological community and all its partners.
The ESR has continued to develop and refine its congress ever since, turning it into the largest radiological meeting in Europe with more than 28,000 participants from around 100 countries and 4,000 scientific papers and exhibits. To answer growing demand, the ECR has developed advanced tools such as EPOS, an online electronic presentation system and ECR Online, providing coverage of the majority of sessions via live video streaming.
Editions
Upcoming Event Date: 27 February - 3 March 2019 Venue: Bruno-Kreisky-Platz 1, 1220 Vienna, Austria
==External links== * [http://www.myesr.org/cms/website.php?id=/en/congress/ecr_2007/about_the_congress/history_of_the_congress.htm History of the congress]{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} from the European Society of Radiology * [http://www.myesr.org/ Official Website] {{primary sources|date=November 2007}}

page.title: Fellow of the Royal Australasian College of Physicians

revision.text:
'''Fellow of the Royal Australasian College of Physicians''', abbreviated as the [[post-nominal]] initials '''FRACP''', is a recognition of the completion of the prescribed postgraduate specialist training programme in internal adult or internal paediatric medicine of the [[Royal Australasian College of Physicians]].
==Fellowship training programme== The fellowship training programme requires that prospective trainees are registered [[medical doctor|medical practitioners]] in [[Australia]] and/or [[New Zealand]].<ref name="Training">{{cite web|url=http://www.racp.edu.au/page/educational-and-professional-development/training-pathways |title=RACP: Training Pathways |publisher=Royal Australasian College of Physician |accessdate=17 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130807110244/http://www.racp.edu.au/page/educational-and-professional-development/training-pathways |archivedate=7 August 2013 |df= }}</ref> Specifically, prospective trainees must have completed a medical degree; completed an intern year; been appointed to an accredited hospital by the College for basic training; discussed their application with, and received approval from, the accredited hospital or a Director of Physician Education.<ref name="Basic">{{cite web|url=http://www.racp.edu.au/page/educational-and-professional-development/prep-basic-training |title=RACP: PREP Basic Training |publisher=Royal Australasian College of Physicians |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130807171953/http://www.racp.edu.au/page/educational-and-professional-development/prep-basic-training |archivedate=2013-08-07 |df= }}</ref> International medical graduates must complete the [[Australian Medical Council]] Certificate in addition to the aforementioned requirements.<ref name="Basic"/>
Multiple pathways lead to fellowship, but all pathways require significant amount of training, time and commitment and consist of three main stages:<ref name="Training"/> *Basic training; *RACP examinations; and, *Advanced training.
The qualification of FRACP is awarded for training programmes in adult internal medicine and in paediatrics and child health. Both programmes have a similar structure, but the content and examinations are accordingly different.<ref name="Training"/>
===Basic training=== Basic training, formally the Royal Australasian College of Physicians's Physician Readiness for Expert Practice (PREP), consists of a series of 36 months of accredited hospital posts, approved by local directors of physician training. These posts encompass a variety of [[medical specialty|medical specialties]]; emergency medicine; and tertiary centre, regional, and rural hospital rotations.<ref name="Basic"/>
The programme must contain prescribed proportions of the aforementioned areas and locations and is assessed by ongoing continuous assessment by the candidate's supervising physicians.<ref name="Basic"/>
Basic training is approximately equivalent to the internal medicine [[Residency (medicine)|residency program]] in the [[United States]] or core medical training programme in the [[United Kingdom]].
===RACP examinations=== After 24 months of basic training, trainees become eligible to sit the external RACP examinations. These consist of a written and a clinical examination. The written examination consists of multiple-choice questions and is held once a year in March. The clinical examination, consisting of two long cases and four short cases, is examined by two assessors (per case) and is held in July, after successful completion of the written exam. Both examinations must be successfully completed before a trainee may progress to advanced training.
The written examination is analogous to the [[American Board of Internal Medicine|board certification examination for internal medicine]] in the United States and the [[Membership of the Royal College of Physicians|MRCP]] Part 1 and 2 (written) exams in the United Kingdom. Unlike the United States and United Kingdom examinations, however, the RACP examinations do not confer an award or qualification upon their successful completion; instead, the entire RACP programme must be successfully completed for the award and qualification of FRACP.
The RACP examinations are the primary hurdle to becoming a specialist physician and are noted for being among the most difficult specialty exams in the world,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imsanz.org.au/training/how-to-pass-the-insiders-guide-to-the-racp-examinations|title=''How to Pass: The Insider's Guide to the RACP Examinations''|publisher=Internal Medicine Society of Australia and New Zealand}}</ref> with an average first-attempt fail rate of approximately 50%.{{citation needed|date=August 2013}}
===Advanced training=== Advanced training consists of a programme of 3–4 years, depending on the requirements of the specialty, of training in a specialty of the trainee's choosing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.racp.edu.au/page/educational-and-professional-development/advanced-training |title=RACP: Advanced Training |publisher=Royal Australasian College of Physicians |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130807123625/http://www.racp.edu.au/page/educational-and-professional-development/advanced-training |archivedate=2013-08-07 |df= }}</ref> A trainee must meet the requirements of the specialty advisory group via undertaking, for instance, clinical training in hospital posts, research, or clinical training in overseas hospital posts or research overseas. Multiple specialisations and subspecialisations are possible,{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} but this is associated with increases in training time.
Unlike the United States, Canada, Europe, and the United Kingdom,{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} most specialties do not require an exit examination.{{which|date=August 2013}}{{citation needed|date=August 2013}}
==Recognition== {{Cleanup-rewrite|date=August 2013|2=section}} {{unreferenced|section|date=July 2016}} Fellowship appears to be a highly regarded qualification, given the extended and rigorous training program,the wide experience & knowledge base, and general commitment required for its attainment.
Fellowship of the [[Royal Australasian College of Physicians]](or its recognised equivalent) is a requirement to be recognised as a Specialist or Consultant Physician, in General (Internal) Medicine or the relevant subspecialty, in Australia and New Zealand. A formal complex process (for recognition of equivalence) is needed for specialists who possess overseas specialist qualifications but who do not possess the FRACP. The requirements change from time to time. External commentators, such as Mr [[Peter Garling]], [[Senior Counsel|SC]], have described these processes as 'onerous' during a 2008 statutory inquiry.
FRACP or its recognised equivalent, in Australia, also allows some Physicians to be recognised as specialists within the Health Insurance Act 1973, and therefore charges incurred by patients when consulting them, may be reimbursed in whole or part by the [[Australian Government]]. In Australia, like in the UK and some other jurisdictions, the FRACP (and other fellowships) does not give the right to statutory registration as a medical practitioner: it is the basic medical degree which does.
Accountability for the quality of the examination processes within the RACP is of the highest standard and widely envied by other similar International bodies. The clinical examination process requires rigorous calibration of all examiners (mandatory) and assessment of all candidates against the clinical skills required of Consultation Physicians in Australia - history taking, clinical analytical abilities and clinical Skills. Evaluation of the clinical examiners includes assessment by other (often more experienced) examiners and high level peer review (by at least 1 other examiner at a local level, and by 6-9 at the national level, always in combination). The National Examinations Panel (NEP) consist of 97 adult physicians selected by their prior examination performance and who represent the geographical spread and specialist range of clinical internal medicine skills in Australia and New Zealand.
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Fellows of the Royal Australasian College of Physicians| ]] [[Category:Professional titles and certifications]] [[Category:New Zealand people in health professions]]
[[sv:Fellow of the Royal Australasian College of Physicians]]

The '''French National AIDS Council''' ([[French language|French]]: Conseil national du sida)) is an advisory body established in 1989 with a mission of “to offer its views on the problems faced by society as a result of AIDS and to make useful suggestions to the government”.
==External links== *[http://www.cns.sante.fr/spip.php?rubrique1&lang=en Official site] *[http://sante-sports.gouv.fr Ministère de la santé, de la jeunesse et des sports (French Ministry of Health, Youth, and Sports) ] *[http://has-sante.fr Haute Autorité de Santé (French National Health Authority)] *[http://invs.sante.fr Institut national de Veille Sanitaire (Health Intelligence Institute) ] *[http://inpes.sante.fr Institut National de Prévention et d’Education à la Santé (National Institute for Prevention and Health Education) ] *[http://www.unaids.org UNAIDS ] *[http://www.who.int WHO] *[http://www.theglobalfund.org The Global Foundation to fight against AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria] *[http://ecdc.europa.eu ECDC ]
